Who needs banknotes? According to a survey by payments company Worldpay, six out of 10 young adults would prefer not to use cash at all.

When Transport for London banned cash on the buses in mid-2014, it was greeted with a backlash from some quarters; â€œpassenger furyâ€� said one headline, â€œban hits the vulnerableâ€� was another. Yet, two years on, behaviour has adjusted. TfL says it has saved Â£24m in cash-handling costs, and queues have improved.

The cashless society has been long mooted, but only now is it arriving. A 1996 trial in Swindon to encourage the townâ€™s 150,000-plus people to use â€œelectronic pursesâ€� flopped through lack of interest. But contactless cards â€“ there are now more than 36m in Britainâ€™s wallets â€“ and more recently Apple Pay and Android Pay, have dramatically accelerated the switch away from cash.

Crucially, it has been the readiness of big retailers to accept â€œtap-and-goâ€� technology for small-value items, with Tesco and TfL at the forefront, that has spurred the revolution. Monthly spending on contactless cards is now running at around Â£1.5bn, or three times the level of just a year ago.

Technology experts see contactless payment as just a stepping stone to the cashless society, with smartphones becoming the main way to pay. Since the launch of Apple Pay in July last year, 8 million journeys on London Underground have been paid for by iPhone users tapping their handset at entry and exit points. Meanwhile, Googleâ€™s rival, Android Pay, was launched last month. Unlike contactless cards, where spending is capped at Â£30, Apple and Android users can spend more freely, although they may have to authenticate with a Pin or fingerprint.

Traditional Pin-entry debit spending is fast being dumped by the public in favour of tap-and-go. A Pret a Manger source says: â€œSixty five per cent of all card transactions at Pret are made using contactless technology,â€� adding that it has a Â£250 limit for Android Pay, although that would pay for rather a lot of dolphin-friendly tuna baguettes.

â€œSmartphones are the final nail in the coffin for cash,â€� says Dave Birch, director of innovation at Consult Hyperion, which helped TfL launch contactless payments. â€œWe all thought it was going to be cards, but itâ€™s going to be phones that do for cash. With a mobile phone you can both pay and be paid â€“ using Pingit and Paym. And, if you look at Uber, itâ€™s not about tap and go, it all happens within your phone. Tapping is a bit of a sideshow. Iâ€™m not convinced that in a decade weâ€™ll be tapping, anyway; we call it moving from â€˜checkoutâ€™ to â€˜check-inâ€™. Your Waitrose app on your phone will know who you are as soon as you walk in the store, and youâ€™ll use your fingerprint to buy as you go around.â€�

Worldpay, which handles 42% of payment processing in the UK, says the next more immediate step to cashlessness will be convincing every small independent shop and trader in the country to adopt contactless terminals. They donâ€™t come free; a newsagent has to pay around Â£20 a month to rent a terminal, or upwards of Â£300-Â£500 to buy one, and more for software updates. The card companies will also take their cut, often 1% of every transaction.

But Worldpay UKâ€™s marketing director, James Frost, who is behind the companyâ€™s â€œhigh street to i-streetâ€� project, reckons take-up will be swift. â€œPeople forget there is a cost to businesses from using cash; you have to pay for security, insurance, making regular trips to the banks. Then thereâ€™s that thing euphemistically called â€˜shrinkageâ€™ â€“ when money goes missing. You donâ€™t have those sorts of headaches with contactless.â€�

He predicts that conventional cash tills, with their drawers for notes and coins and mini-printers for receipts, will soon disappear from shops, replaced by tablet-based terminals linked to contactless readers, with e-receipts sent to phones.

Around one in 10 small shops still refuse card payments for small purchases, usually below Â£5, but are expected to come in line as they are deserted by younger shoppers only prepared to use their phones.

Cashless enthusiasts argue the black economy will be hugely diminished, and tax evasion made far more difficult â€“ though privacy campaigners worry about the harvesting of huge amounts of new data. Bond fund supremo Jim Leaviss â€“ in charge of M&Gâ€™s Â£40bn in retail fixed-interest assets â€“ reckons the move to a cashless society could even help end boom and bust in the economy.

Outside Londonâ€™s South Kensington station stands an unlikely early adopter of the cashless revolution â€“ Big Issue seller Simon Mott. Three years ago, he got an iZettle account to take card payments. Now he accepts Apple Pay and Android Pay.

Charities whose rattling boxes are falling silent as cashless pedestrians pass by are among those most urgently trying to find new ways to obtain donations.

Will cash machines on British high streets become as redundant as red phone boxes, a relic of yesterdayâ€™s technology? Peter McNamara, chief executive of NoteMachine, which runs 9,000 ATMs across Britain and Germany, might be expected to refute that, but he makes a good point: On the 2 May bank holiday in the UK, more cash was withdrawn from ATMs in Britain than at any other time in history â€“ Â£1.72bn on the day, and 7% more than the same bank holiday the year before.

The death of cash has been exaggerated, he says. â€œConsumers still need and use cash â€“ more so than ever before. The reason cash continues to prevail is because it gives us freedom. It will not be rejected by a third party, it is reliable and it enables us all to manage our personal finances with ease.

â€œThere is a real danger that the UK is being railroaded towards a cashless society, with the agenda driven hard by technology giants and card issuers who are keen to capitalise on the digital age â€“ yet the evidence to support this suggests hype rather than reality.â€�

A major milestone on the path to a cashless society was passed in 2015, the first year that consumers used cash for less than half of all payments, according to Payments UK, which represents the major banks, building societies and payment providers. But perhaps mindful of the outcry that greeted an early plan to ban cheques, Payments UK has no plans to follow Nordic countries down the path of banning cash. It predicts that cash usage will not be eclipsed by debit cards and contactless until 2021.

Meanwhile, even those who have declared war on cash warn about the losers. Birch says: â€œThereâ€™s a class issue here. A lot of middle-class people already go from one day to the next without using cash. About the only time they use lots of cash is to pay a builder to avoid VAT. Poorer people are far more trapped in cash and the costs that go with it. They are the ones withdrawing Â£10 from a machine and paying Â£1.50 for it. We donâ€™t, as yet, have an equivalent to M-Pesa in Kenya, a mobile account for everyone.â€�

So itâ€™s Kenya, not Scandinavia, that may have the key to a cashless future. Just remember to keep your phone charged; in future, your journey to work, lunch and popping into the shops will be at the mercy of your battery.

These days we think of cash as a means of putting food on the table, but there was a time when currency could have been used to eat it too.

Around 3,000 years ago, Chinese societies used small metal replicas of tools, such as knives and spades, as currency.

As time went on and people grew tired of skewering their hands every time they reached into their pocket to settle a bill, the metal currency became round and flat â€“ the origin of todayâ€™s coinage.

It wasnâ€™t until around 600BC in Lydia, in modern-day Turkey, that the first coins were minted en masse and stamped to denote different denominations.

The practice spread into Europe and todayâ€™s de facto global currency, the US dollar, has its roots in the â€œthalerâ€�, a silver coin dating back to the mid-15th century. The name comes from the town of Joachimsthal in Bohemia, where silver mines were used to produce coins originally known as â€œJoachimsthalerâ€�.

We also have China to thank for the advent of paper money, first used in the Tang dynasty, which lasted from AD618 to AD907.

The bills mostly took the form of letters of credit linked to specific transactions, but were a precursor to modern paper notes.

It took Europe about another 500 years to catch on, but lenders and banks eventually started issuing notes that could be taken to a branch and exchanged for silver and gold.

A shift towards governments printing their own bills gathered pace with the colonisation of North America. The long transatlantic journeys meant that colonists often ran out of cash, so paper IOUs became usable as currency, issued to soldiers and then spreading through the economy.

Many governments still donâ€™t print their own money or mint their own coins, instead paying other countries and private companies â€“ such as Basingstoke-based De La Rue â€“ to do it for them.

Britainâ€™s Royal Mint produces coins on behalf of dozens of other countriesâ€™ governments. However, it does not disclose the identities of these governments for fear that their decision to outsource money-printing will cause embarrassment back home.

6.09pm BST

And finally, back to Microsoftâ€™s proposed $26bn purchase of LinkedIn, and the hefty earnings multiple it is paying:

Meanwhile the deal could see increased competition for US group Salesforce, says Julia Langley, partner at advisory group Results International:

Microsoftâ€™s core business is built around enterprise productivity software. Theyâ€™ve been increasingly under threat from all sorts of players competing for pole position in this space.

Google and Facebook, two of the biggest tech companies in the world with strong consumer propositions have moved heavily into this enterprise area, with Facebook at Work and Google for Work.

Doing nothing was not an option for Microsoft, hence this massive, bold coup.

LinkedIn is one of the best new business/sales tools in the world of B2B and in many ways competes head on with Salesforce. ... If anyone is going to be feeling unnerved by the deal, itâ€™s Salesforce. We should expect to see some sort of announcement from then in the months ahead.

The competition watchdog is to investigate suspected market rigging by energy price comparison websites.

The investigation will examine whether websites agreed not to compete with each other when consumers searched on Google for the best deals.

The Competition and Markets Authority said: â€œThe CMA is investigating a suspected breach of competition law by some price comparison websites that offer energy tariff comparisons in relation to paid online search advertising.â€�

But in a bizarre twist, the initial investigation by the industry regulator, Ofgem, has been switched to the CMA after Ofgem uncovered earlier dealings by its own staff with the comparison sites that could have called into question the impartiality of the investigation.

Ofgem said it found that two or more of the comparison sites had, since 2010, â€œbeen parties to an agreement or concerted practice relating to bidding and/or negative matching for search advertising which have as their object or effect the prevention, restriction or distortion of competition.â€�

These practices included â€œagreements not to compete in relation to particular search terms used for the purposes of online search advertisingâ€�.

Negative matching is when an advertiser indicates to a search engine operator such as Google that it does not want its website to appear in the search results for specific keywords.

Ofgem has not named the parties it is investigating in relation to the suspected collusion. But in a statement, comparison site uSwitch said: â€œWe have supported Ofgem with information in relation to this matter and will provide the CMA with any further information, if asked. This case is currently at an information gathering phase as the Ofgem decision notice specifies. We have no further detail on the nature of the case.â€�

The issue was handed to the CMA after an initial investigation by the industry regulator Ofgem was at risk of being compromised by actions of Ofgem staff.

Ofgem found its staff had, before the formal investigation begun, been in contact with the websites now under investigation, encouraging them to change their behaviour when it came to buying advertising on search engines such as Google. Once the investigation began, Ofgem realised its earlier activities could call into question the regulatorâ€™s own impartiality.

In a statement, Ofgem said: â€œOfgem itself procured search advertising during the period under investigation in the course of publishing advice and information to promote the interests of consumers, one of our statutory functions.

Related: UK watchdog accused of bowing to pressure from 'big six' energy suppliers

â€œOfgem became aware of communications between Ofgem staff and representatives of some of the parties under investigation encouraging those parties to change their behaviour in relation to bidding on search advertising keywords relevant to Ofgem. These communications took place before the investigation was opened.

â€œOfgem considers that this could delay the progress of the case, for example if parties were to call into question Ofgemâ€™s impartiality in continuing with the case.â€�

The CMA said that it will decide in August whether to proceed with the investigation or to close it.

It was revealed in June last year that Moneysupermarket and uSwitch had been asked by Ofgem to provide information regarding a separate investigation into commission rates they charge energy suppliers, but in March this year the investigation was closed with no further action.

The CMAâ€™s wider investigation into energy markets â€“ which critics fear has bowed to pressure from the â€œbig sixâ€� energy providers â€“ will issue its final report on Friday 24 June, the day after the EU referendum.

5.47pm BST

Summary: Green rejects blame in six-hour Philibuster

That was the longest and most confrontational parliamentary session Iâ€™ve covered over the last decade.

Sir Philip Green went into the grilling vowing to put his side of the story, and he took every opportunity to do so â€“ interrupting MPs, refusing to answer questions he didnâ€™t fancy, and taking criticism extremely badly.

Broadly, his position is that some mistakes were made, but itâ€™s not really his fault. He doesnâ€™t want to blame anyone else, but managed to blame pretty much everyone who had a role in this fiasco - advisers, the pension regulator and even journalists.

He seemed particularly irked with City firms Olswang and Grant Thornton for representing Dominic Chappell, suggesting they provided a sheen of respectability.

Thatâ€™s a pretty poor excuse for not realising that the ex-bankrupt racing driver might not be the best person to buy BHS.

Green did at least apologise, nice and early in the session, and admit he should never have sold the company to Chappell for Â£1.

But he also claimed that recent criticism was â€œwhollyâ€� unfair, and even blamed â€œenvy and jealousyâ€� for the dividends which moved from BHS to his luxury base in Monaco.

Green is entitled to his point of view, but perhaps he should save the lectures until the BHS pension deficit has been fixed.

The committee struggled to land many punches on Green over the financial details of the BHS farrago. Thatâ€™s because the Arcadia chief had a two-pronged strategy; he either produced his own figures to challenge the MPs, or claimed he simply didnâ€™t get involved with whatever they were asking about. For example, the sale of BHSâ€™s Ealing store to his stepson.

Instead, Green preferred to focus on other wrong-doing - such as Chappellâ€™s apparent breach of the covenants set up to protect BHS.

Green did have the excuse that his wife, Lady Christina, actually owns Arcadiaâ€™s assets. Did the committee call the wrong Green? Perhaps Tina should sail one of the familyâ€™s yachts up the Thames and testify herself....

BHS pensioners did get one piece of good news - Greenâ€™s pledge to address the pension black hole. He said:

â€œI want to give an assurance to the 20,000 [BHS] pensioners that I am there to sort this, in the correct way.â€�

However, Green did not promise to ensure they would receive their full entitlement; instead, it might just be better than taking a cut in the Payment Protection Fund.

Green was also rather hazy about how the scheme fell into such a mess, insisting that heâ€™d not bled the company dry but had actually invested capital in it.

Greenâ€™s aggressive attitude seemed to stun MPs at first; he slammed one member for excessive staring, and snarled â€œI canâ€™t deal with thisâ€� when asked a pretty fair question about whether heâ€™d deliberately offloaded BHSâ€™s pension liabilities.

After a while they began to suspect that it might hold the key to the crisis. The committee may well conclude that the BHS disaster might have been averted if Arcadiaâ€™s chairman had been more open to criticism. A corporate governance problem, indeed.

Green also showed that heâ€™s not at the cutting edge of technology â€“ we got a glimpse of his antiquated Nokia mobile phone, after he failed to turn it off following a break.

Some younger viewers may have been baffled by the small booklet he waved at MPs at one stage; thatâ€™s called a cheque book, kids. And Green may well have to get it out again, and write a nine-figure sum to patch up the black hole in BHSâ€™s pension.

Thatâ€™s all from me today. Thanks for reading and commenting. Goodnight. GW

Updated at 6.24pm BST

4.46pm BST

Chris Martin, chair of the BHS pension trustees, has told Sky News that he hopes Green will make an offer that means pensioners will receive more than theyâ€™d get through the Pension Protection Fund.

And that means Green stumping up more than Â£100m, Martin adds.

4.33pm BST

Hereâ€™s a snap of Green leaving the Houses of Parliament after being questioned by MPs today.

4.32pm BST

I missed this earlier, but there was a small protest outside parliament, urging Green to save his reputation and cover the BHS pension black hole.

4.29pm BST

MPs: Green must satisfy public opinion

Iain Wright and Frank Field have issued a statement, warning Green that he may have to dig deep into his pocket to satisfy public anger over the collapse of BHS.

The two MPs also warn Green that he may have to answer further questions:

â€œWe thank Sir Philip for giving us six hours of evidence in Parliament today, and we were pleased to hear that he is still trying to put together a better deal for the BHS pensioners. We hope he will come up with an offer that is satisfactory to The Pension Regulator. However, he doesnâ€™t only have to satisfy The Pensions Regulator, today he is before the bar of public opinion. Much of his reputation now depends on how generously he responds.

â€œTodayâ€™s evidence raised host of further questions and we first want to get much more detail on the structure of various companies, particularly those owned by Lady Cristina Green, the profits they have made and the tax they have paid.

â€œWe have more witnesses scheduled at the end of June and in the last few days we have received a huge amount of further evidence. We have many further questions for Sir Philip, particularly the big questions on the pension fund that he was unable to answer today.â€�

4.00pm BST

Field: Green needs to make generous pension deal

Frank Field, head of the work and pensions committee, says that Sir Philip Greenâ€™s credibility is now on the line.

His reputation as a top business chief now hangs on his willingness to support BHS pensioners, says Field, speaking to my colleague Sarah Butler.

Updated at 6.25pm BST

3.23pm BST

The pension regulator has swiftly responded to Greenâ€™s evidence.

In a statement, it denies refusing to engage with Sir Philip Green.

It also states that it hasnâ€™t received any â€œnew proposalsâ€�.

3.12pm BST

And finally, as Big Ben rings 3pm, Green repeats his pledge to sit down with the pensions regulator and talk about the pension scheme.

I want to get this over quicker than you do, he pledges. And he promises to do all he can to support any deal to save BHS.

And that is finally the end of the meeting, after a near six-hour marathon.

3.07pm BST

Green blasts "envy and jealousy" over tax set-up

Q: With hindsight, do you think the offshore setup of your businesses is incompatible with the modern world?

Green checks his pad for a prepared statement, and then pronounces

Envy and jealousy are two incurable diseases. I have done nothing wrong.

Green insists that his empire could have been structured much more aggressively to avoid tax.

We have paid many, many hundreds of millions of pounds of tax. As far I am concerned I have a very clear conscience. We have paid everything due.

Green suggests that he could, for example, have taken his fashion brands offshore and charged a royalty.

Where we made money here, we paid tax here.

3.01pm BST

Green: Criticism has been unbalanced and unfair

Q: What lessons can we learn from the BHS failure, to help rebuild the publicâ€™s trust in the capitalist system?

Green sayâ€™s heâ€™s immune to criticism after the last few weeks, which have meant heâ€™s been unable to visit his stores.

Q: Do you feel hounded?

The criticism has been wholly unbalanced and unfair, Green says, a little mournfully.

I made a bad call selling this business to RAL [Chappellâ€™s Retail Acquisitions], Green says. But other people made mistakes too, including lawyers, and now everyone says itâ€™s just my fault.

Iâ€™m a big boy, I can take a punch on the chin.... but I didnâ€™t do this deliberately, he concludes.

Updated at 3.16pm BST

2.57pm BST

Q: Do you think your reputation has been improved by todayâ€™s session?

Green declines to mark his own homework, but hopes that people understand what happened at BHS.

Iâ€™ve had quite a few supportive emails and texts from BHS staff, he adds.

Q: What would you like your legacy to be, in a yearâ€™s time?

Green looks baffled, saying even heâ€™s not clever enough to undo the past.

Then he talks about the work that Arcadia does in the fashion industry, encouraging young talent.

â€œAll people in BHS know Iâ€™m honest and no way I would have wanted this kind of ending.â€�

In other words, heâ€™s not a bad guy, honest...

2.54pm BST

Q: Would you consider buying BHS back if you could get the pension issue sorted?

No, Green insists. Life has moved on.

Not for the 11,000 staff at BHS, the committee point out.

Q: So who are the winners from the BHS story?

No-one, Green says, adding.

I think it was a very sad episode. Everything that could have gone wrong, did go wrong.

Q: So who are the losers?

Thatâ€™s easy, Green says. The staff and the pensioners.

2.51pm BST

Green demands apology over "ego" jibe

Green then confirms that he attended a meeting with Mike Ashley and the administrators on 27 April, at Arcadiaâ€™s offices.

He produces a letter from the administrator saying Arcadia offered to add Â£5m to Sports Directâ€™s bid for BHS and did not frustrate the deal.

Q: So why did it fail?

Because of one of these, says Green, producing his chequebook.

And he denies that he did anything to block Mike Ashley from taking control

On what possible basis would I want to stop someone buying BHS?

â€œEgoâ€�, says Iain Wright.

Green looks *furious*. â€œThatâ€™s really rude,â€� he says, and out of order. He says Wright should apologise.

Green starts to assembles his papers, muttering that heâ€™s glad the meeting is over.

But itâ€™s not over quite yet

Updated at 3.16pm BST

2.47pm BST

The session turns rowdy, now, as Iain Wright probes Sports Directâ€™s attempts to rescue BHS.

He gets Philip Green to confirm that he didnâ€™t know Mike Ashley (Sports Directâ€™s founder) was trying to sort out a deal.

And Wright then produces a letter from Ashley, which states that the two men did have contact.

Green tries to interrupt, telling Wright to stop bullying him (!) and claiming that heâ€™s in charge of what he says.

Green then explains that he didnâ€™t know that Chappell held all-night talks on Thursday 21 April, until the Friday lunchtime Chappell asked Green for Ashleyâ€™s phone number.

He reveals that he then had a jokey conversation with Ashley, but insists that he has zero knowledge about the negotiations.

Q: So how much contact did you have over the weekend?

We may have spoken a few times, Green concedes.

2.39pm BST

The committee turn to the events of April, when BHS went into administration.

Green denies that he triggered it - even though he refused to accept that Â£60m loan from Gordon Brothers.

But then Iain Wright MP reads a letter from the administrators, Duff and Phelps, showing that Green has asked him to attend a meeting.

Green explains that he was told on Friday 22 April that an unknown retailer was attempting a last-ditch rescue bid, but he didnâ€™t know who [I think this is Sports Direct].

But if it didnâ€™t transpire, he [Green] was concerned that staff wouldnâ€™t be paid the next week if a deal wasnâ€™t agreed.

2.31pm BST

Green looks like he might mislay his rag, when asked to clarify his commitment to BHS pensioners.

We covered that five and half hours ago, he says, before repeating that he will meet with the pension regulator and try to agree a deal.

2.29pm BST

Green also explains that he wasnâ€™t prepared to support a Â£60m loan from investment group Gordon Brothers which Chappell had lined up in the final days before BHS went under.

It was a â€œloan to ownâ€�, says Green, as BHS would have breached it quickly.... meaning Gordon Brothers would have walked away with the business.

Updated at 2.32pm BST

2.27pm BST

Q: Dominic Chappell told us that he was shocked that you sold the BHS Ealing branch to your stepson, and he flipped it for a Â£3.5m profit. Is that true?

I wasnâ€™t involved in that deal, Green replies. It wasnâ€™t my transaction.

Q: But did you know about it?

Green doesnâ€™t give a particularly clear answer, but indicates he was aware the property was being sold.

Q: Is it true that you initially told the regulator that you had not sold any assets to any interested parties, and then had to correct it once the Ealing sale came to light?

Is which bit true, asks Green?

Q: That you initially told the regulator that you had not sold any assets to any interested parties, and then had to correct it?

Green says he doesnâ€™t know.

Q: Well, could you help us check?

Green says this line of questioning is â€œludicrousâ€�.

2.17pm BST

Green: I didn't want BHS to fail.

Q: Did you have regular talks to Chappell about weekly sales?

No, says Green. Chappell wouldnâ€™t know what they were.

Q: And you sold him the company...

Donâ€™t remind me, Green grimaces.

And he jokes:

If you look Dominic Chappell up in the dictionary it says â€œvery optimisticâ€�

Q: Do what did you talk to Chappell about?

I didnâ€™t want to the business to fail, Green insists, so he acted as a sounding board for Chappellâ€™s ideas.

Green also disses Chappellâ€™s claims to be a property expert, saying he failed to cut a better deal with landlords.

Chappell was also too slow to arrange the CVA [Company Voluntary Arrangement] which trimmed BHSâ€™s rent costs, Green adds. That stubbornness undermined the chances of turning BHS around.

Updated at 2.19pm BST

2.14pm BST

2.11pm BST

Green now wants the committee clerk to stop whispering to MPs during the session.

2.10pm BST

It looks like Green uses an old-school Nokia handset...

2.08pm BST

Suddenly, a mobile phone rings, disrupting the session....and itâ€™s Sir Philâ€™s!

Apologies, he says, I forgot to turn it off.

Itâ€˜s the pensions regulator, jokes Iain Wright.

2.06pm BST

The committee are back again for the final part of the session.

Sir Philip Green seems quite chirpy still - maybe he can see the finishing line in sight.

Jeremy Quin MP asks about the charges that he retained on BHS after selling it, which meant Arcadia was a preferred creditor.

Green says that out of Â£256m of debt, Â£216m was written off when BHS was sold and a Â£40m charge was retained.

He says that he also agreed to released a fixed charge on one property, to help the new owners raise more money

Q: So you had an umbilical connection...

Iâ€™m sorry, I canâ€™t accept that, Green interrupts, showing that thin-skinned side again.

1.44pm BST

OK, the committee are taking another quick break for a vote, but they will be back shortly.

Green would happily have finished the session right then.

1.44pm BST

Green is arguing that he didnâ€™t realise that Chappell was unreliable...

1.37pm BST

Green says one of the â€œlovely journalists in the roomâ€� contributed to BHSâ€™s demise, by undermining Chappellâ€™s credibility each weekend.

Those articles made it impossible to get credit insurance for BHS, he claims.

Iâ€™m pretty sure he means Oliver Shah of the Sunday Times, who has swiftly responded:

Updated at 1.38pm BST

1.34pm BST

Green: Chappell "breached covenants" over BHS deal

Onto another curious property deal, the sale of North West House (a BHS asset sold in 2015).

Green says that it was sold to Â£32m, but only Â£25m showed up in the BHS accounts. Arcadia were told that remaining Â£7m had been transferred to the Bank of China, to help set up a Â£100m loan.

He says that the Â£7m then arrived at Chappellâ€™s lawyers, Olswang. But Â£1.2m was then paid to Olswang, Â£1.2m to Grant Thornton, Â£1.8m to Chappell himself....

This, Green declares. means that Chappell breached a covenant which Arcadia had made him sign, to not take money out of the business (as our Sarah Butler reported earlier this month)

1.25pm BST

MP: Does Green have a corporate governance problem?

Philip Green is getting ill-tempered again, as the committee ask how he compensated Chappell for the Â£8.5m profit that he didnâ€™t get on the Marylebone House deal.

He keep trying to sweep away questions he doesnâ€™t like the sound of.

And Iain Wright MP has spotted a pattern - suggesting that Greenâ€™s Arcadia Group has a serious corporate governance problem.

Thatâ€™s your opinion, Green says.

If you behaves like this in a parliamentary committee, it must be hard for directors to raise concerns at an Arcadia board meeting, suggests Richard Fuller MP.

Iâ€™m choosing to ignore that, says Green.

1.19pm BST

Green confirms that he had planned to sell Marylebone House, BHSâ€™s HQ, to Chappell for Â£35m.

He insists that he simply wasnâ€™t involved until 2012 (!) But weâ€™ve been told that youâ€™re a Napoleon of industry, explains Frank Field MP, the man in control of everything. Weâ€™re struggling to acclimatise to this new image of you... Green looks hurt, saying: I havenâ€™t run away, I havenâ€™t tried to run away. He hits out at the â€œoutrageous and pretty rude media coverageâ€� in recent months, which have created quite the wrong impression. And he then issues a second apology, for the pension deficit: Iâ€˜m happy to apologise, I should have been involved earlier. For whatever reason I wasnâ€™t, but I should have been involved earlier. Onto the BHS pensions black hole.... Green says that the pension deficit should have been tackled as soon as he bought the company. But he also argues that itâ€™s not his fault, blaming â€œpoor communicationâ€� on both sides. He also reveals he only spoke to the BHS pension trustees on a handful of occasions Green also tries to spread the blame around, saying a lot of money was paid to pension advisers -- Â£650,000 in the early days, rising to â€œnorth of Â£1.5mâ€� by 2005-06. Q: Why is the Â£380m dividend figure different than the Â£423m weâ€™ve heard earlier? Green airily says heâ€™d just reading out the numbers handed by his finance team, arguing that he doesnâ€™t really get involved with the money side of things. I wouldnâ€™t even know who to phone to take money out of our bank. Fuller insists he doesnâ€™t want to make Green uncomfortable, as everyone stares at Green in disbelief. Green looks a bit surprised by this approach, replying that â€œitâ€™s not right to mark your own essayâ€�. [they loaned Chappell Â£35m, and were planning to buy BHSâ€™s HQ, Marylebone House] Why did you sell Marylebone House to Arcadia when there were external buyers? That includes investigating curious property deals which appeared to be designed to help make Chappell look like a credible bidder. And probably most importantly, they need to press Green hard on the BHS pension deficit (currently Â£571m). Why didnâ€™t he fix this problem before the sale, rather than leaving it in Chappellâ€™s tender clutches? And what will he do to fix the mess now? Greenâ€™s reputation has been badly damaged by the unfolding drama around BHS already. His credibility is on the line. Rolls-Royce has unveiled its first driverless vehicle, a concept car that promises to help its owner announce their importance to the world.

The Vision Next 100 is an autonomous vehicle aimed at â€œthe most discerning and powerful patrons in the worldâ€�. It has no steering wheel and a silk â€œthroneâ€� from which its occupants can watch the world go by.

Rolls-Royce said the zero-emission model, codenamed 103EX, showed the company â€œrejects the notion of anonymous, utilitarian and bland future modes of mobilityâ€�.

In a statement that was short on technical specifications but packed with florid description, Rolls-Royce promised an interior made only of â€œthe most precious and contemporary eleganceâ€�.

The owner will be â€œencircled by the most modern handcrafted fine-line Macassar wood panellingâ€� as they gaze at a â€œgenerousâ€� high-definition television screen.

Their comfort will be ensured not by an ordinary car seat, but by a â€œbeautifully textured, ivory-coloured luxurious throne upon which our passengers are conveyed, and from which they commandâ€�.

Their feet will be cushioned by â€œthe finest one-off deep-pile ivory wool carpetâ€�, while anyone worried about leg room will be satisfied thanks to extra space afforded by â€œthe removal of the chauffeurâ€�.

Instead of a driver, passengers can give orders to a virtual assistant named Eleanor â€“ after the actor Eleanor Thornton, who is rumoured to have inspired the carâ€™s Spirit of Ecstasy bonnet ornament.

Eleanor will act as a concierge â€œimbued with her own artificial intelligenceâ€� and capable of reminding the owner not to miss meetings and even bringing the car around to the front of their house at the start of a journey.

Rolls-Royce, owned by BMW, said the car proved that â€œcertain truths are constant over timeâ€�, such as the notion that â€œthe powerful have always understood the symbols through which they express their standingâ€�.

â€œThe very size of the Rolls-Royce Vision Next 100 announces the importance of its precious cargo,â€� the carmaker explained, pointing to its vast dimensions â€“ 5.9 metres long and 1.6 metres high.

The glass roof is a â€œcanopy over the occupants that provides privacy while allowing them to contemplate the majesty of the stars in the firmament above as they glide through the nightâ€�.

The space usually reserved for the Rollsâ€™ 12-cylinder engine will give way to a luggage compartment that opens automatically on arrival to present two personalised Grand Tourer cases.

And if the grandeur of the journey inside a vehicle that gives â€œthe impression of a futuristic catamaranâ€� was not enough, the car has something special in store on arrival at the passengersâ€™ destination.

â€œAs the Rolls-Royce Vision Next 100 gracefully comes to a halt, something magnificent occurs,â€� the company said. The glass roof rises to allow the occupant to stand, while a step emerges from below the running board and a red light is projected, â€œcarpet-likeâ€� to announce their arrival.

â€œThus, as in Botticelliâ€™s â€˜Birth of Venusâ€™, our guest is framed and ready to step gracefully into the limelight and greet their audience â€¦ This is automotive haute couture,â€� the company added.

Amid the fanfare accompanying its unveiling, Rolls-Royce did not say how the vehicle, due to hit the streets in the 2040s, would be powered or how it would cope with speed bumps.

And despite the grand language, the concept car met with a mixed response, with technology website Slash Gear describing the vehicle as â€œsublimely crazyâ€�.

Other car fans were even less sympathetic.

A number of companies are working on driverless cars, including Google. Its two-seater looks like a cross between a Smart Car and a Nissan Micra, has no steering wheel, accelerator or brakes, and just two physical controls: â€œstopâ€� and â€œgoâ€�.

Nissan, Toyota, Audi and the ride-hailing service Uber are among those also working on a self-driving technology. Volvo intends to test them on London roads next year.

The Vision Next 100 â€“ the brainchild of Giles Taylor, Rolls-Royceâ€™s director of design â€“ was unveiled at the Roundhouse arts venue in north London on Thursday.

â€œIt is an expression of our intrinsic understanding of the possibilities for a true luxury brand and the desires of its customers,â€� Taylor said.

Amazon is quietly rooting out many of its Chinese traders who do not hold UK VAT numbers to try to protect itself from tax evasion inquiries later this year when new HMRC powers come into force, the Guardian has learned.

The online retailer has been conducting a review of sellersâ€™ VAT compliance in the UK. It is understood to have contacted many Chinese sellers, giving them until the end of the month to provide their VAT numbers.

Recent years have seen an explosion in small, overseas firms using Amazon and other sites to sell to online shoppers in the UK. Large numbers, including many from China, are not charging VAT. As a result, they have been able to reach the â€œbestsellerâ€� rankings, dominating some of the most popular listings on Amazon.

While much attention has been paid in recent years to how Amazon, Apple, Google and other tech groups have arranged their affairs internationally so as to avoid corporation tax, the loss to the UK public purse from the hordes of overseas sellers who have found ways to sell online in the UK without charging VAT may be far greater.

Related: Amazon and eBay to be held liable for VAT fraud by sellers

HMRC has described such VAT evasion as a â€œvery big issueâ€�, estimated to cost up to Â£1.5bn a year in lost tax. But officials have been frustrated by what is seen by some as the uncooperative approach taken by many big websites, including Amazon.

In January, Lin Homer, then head of HMRC, told a parliamentary committee: â€œWe do feel, just as with beer and alcohol, that those people who manage the supply chain should ensure enough diligence is built into it. Marketplace providers have responsibilities.â€�

Amazon has rejected this, insisting widespread VAT fraud is not its concern. The company says it is not responsible for policing the VAT compliance of the hundreds of traders who sell goods in the UK via its site.

Behind the scenes, however, Amazonâ€™s new UK boss, Doug Gurr, who previously led Amazonâ€™s Chinese business, is thought to be keen to avoid a repeat of last yearâ€™s embarrassing revelations about VAT abuses among overseas sellers.

In the run-up to Christmas, a Guardian investigation identified a wave of overseas traders, many based in China, who were using Amazon UK to warehouse and sell a wide range of goods without charging VAT.

In response, George Osborne announced new powers in his March budget to help HMRC police VAT compliance in online retail â€“ including, in some instances, holding marketplace websites such as Amazon liable for missing tax.

The chancellor said these measures would help curb the abuse and restore Â£875m in tax receipts over the next four years.

Gurrâ€™s recent review of seller compliance is not thought to signal a more collaborative approach to combating VAT fraud. In a statement to the Guardian, a spokesperson reiterated: â€œSellers are independent businesses responsible for complying with their own VAT obligations.

â€œWe do offer tools and information to assist sellers with their compliance, but we donâ€™t have the authority to review their tax affairs.â€� Amazon said it did nevertheless cooperate with HMRC when required by law.

The company spokesperson confirmed there were no plans to require Chinese or other overseas traders to display their UK VAT numbers on Amazonâ€™s site.

That decision remains controversial because, under the EUâ€™s e-commerce directive, online sellers are required to make their VAT numbers â€œeasily, directly and permanently accessibleâ€� to customers.

Since the Guardianâ€™s investigation into VAT fraud last year, HMRC has carried out a series of raids on independent warehouses in the UK used by overseas traders, seizing goods worth more than Â£500,000. Officials have also held urgent meetings with top executives at Amazon and eBay to discuss the problem.

Angry UK traders, who have been unable to compete with the new wave of VAT-evading overseas competitors, have called for ministers to clamp down on this widespread tax fraud.

Campaign groups representing UK-based sellers, including Ravas and VATfraud.org, have called for Amazon and other sites used by overseas sellers to be held immediately liable for all lost VAT. But Osborne has declined to go that far.

Instead, new rules announced in his March budget â€“ expected to come into force with the 2016 finance bill â€“ made it clear retail websites would only be held accountable if they failed to act after suspected abuses had been brought to their attention by HMRC.

Guardian investigations into VAT fraud last year involved a Â£1,818.20 sample order placed through Amazon with small overseas seller companies. The order included VAT of Â£0.00.

Among the 24 items ordered were high-value goods such as an Apple watch, iPad, Fitbit and Panasonic camera, as well as cheaper products including a bike light, corkscrew and mobile phone case.

The items were being sold by 23 different seller companies that appeared to have minimal or no business operations in the UK. Nine gave addresses in Hong Kong, eight in China and six in the US. All had arranged for Amazon to hold their stock in the UK, pack and send parcels, and deal with payment and returns queries.

When contacted by email and asked if they could provide a VAT receipt, many of the 23 sellers declined. â€œWe are sorry that we are not VAT registered,â€� said one. Another said: â€œI am sorry to let you know that we couldnâ€™t supply a VAT invoice as we havenâ€™t charge you for that, right?â€�

A third reply said: â€œWe donâ€™t provide the VAT invoice, our product is exclusive of VAT, hope you can understand.â€� Another responded: â€œWe can provide a VAT invoice but for security reasons we donâ€™t supply the VAT number.â€�
